name: PLA
description: PLA is super easy to print, cheap, and available in many colors. It's the stiffest non-composite thermoplastic and has excellent tensile strength.
pros: Easy to print, cheap, stiff, excellent tensile strength.
cons: Susceptible to UV light, shatters when dropped, can't be sanded or glued well.

name: Silk PLA
description: Silk PLA has a special additive that makes your prints shiny. It's more metallic than actual metal but weakens the print.
pros: Shiny, easier to remove supports, aesthetically pleasing.
cons: Weakens the print, can puff up during printing.

name: Carbon Fiber PLA
description: Carbon Fiber PLA sharpens details, stabilizes the filament as it cools, and makes the end product stiffer but more brittle.
pros: Sharpens details, stabilizes cooling, crisp details, low shrinkage, matte finish.
cons: More brittle, requires a hardened steel nozzle.

name: Metal-Filled PLA
description: Metal-filled PLA contains metal shavings that make prints heavier and adds some properties like patina and magnetism.
pros: Heavier, develops patina, magnetic (if iron-filled).
cons: Extremely brittle, expensive, weak.

name: Wood PLA
description: Wood PLA is plastic mixed with sawdust. The quality varies, and it feels like hardwood when finished.
pros: Feels like hardwood, convincing wood grain effect with varnish.
cons: Weaker, absorbs humidity, difficult to print.

name: Tough PLA
description: Tough PLA is a combination of PLA and polybutene terephthalate (PBT). It resists higher temperatures and handles impacts better.
pros: Higher temperature resistance, impact-resistant, doesn't shatter.
cons: None significant for light-duty projects.

name: Matte PLA
description: Matte PLA contains plant pulp, giving prints a springy satin surface. It can be sanded, painted, and carved.
pros: Springy satin surface, can be sanded, painted, and carved.
cons: Absorbs humidity quickly, semi-flexible, can jam in the extruder.

name: High-Speed PLA
description: High-Speed PLA melts at a lower temperature and has reduced viscosity, allowing for faster printing speeds.
pros: Allows for high-speed printing, reduces print time significantly.
cons: Softens at lower temperatures, can be problematic in hot climates.

name: Flex PLA (PCL)
description: Flex PLA (PCL) is a low-temperature printing filament with a waxy consistency, useful for prosthetics and sculptable plastics.
pros: Low-temperature printing, can be reshaped with warm water, useful for prosthetics.
cons: Translucent waxy consistency, no adhesive sticks to it.

name: PETG
description: PETG is tougher than PLA, handles higher temperatures, and is more transparent. It has a low coefficient of friction.
pros: Tough, handles higher temperatures, transparent, low friction.
cons: Poor overhang performance, absorbs water quickly.

name: Carbon Fiber PETG
description: Carbon Fiber PETG stabilizes molten filament, improving stability and support quality. It has a matte finish and is stiffer than regular PETG.
pros: Stabilizes molten filament, improves stability, matte finish.
cons: Expensive, limited suppliers.

name: PCTG
description: PCTG is an improved version of PETG. It is very tough, low-warping, and has almost perfect layer adhesion.
pros: Very tough, low-warping, excellent layer adhesion.
cons: Expensive, hard to find, difficult to remove supports.

name: PET
description: PET is stiffer and tougher than PETG, with better resistance to high temperatures. However, it is harder to print.
pros: Stiffer and tougher, better high-temperature resistance.
cons: Harder to print, worse overhang and warping issues.

name: CF PET
description: CF PET is easier to print than entry-level PETG and is extremely stiff, making it suitable for high-performance parts.
pros: Easy to print, extremely stiff.
cons: Expensive, requires a high-performance printer.

name: PVB
description: PVB is a weaker filament but reveals its true colors when exposed to alcohol, fusing layers together for a smooth finish.
pros: Smooth finish with alcohol vapor smoothing.
cons: Weaker, fuses together easily, hard to print.

name: ABS
description: ABS is tough and withstands high temperatures. It can be solvent-welded and vapor-smoothed with acetone.
pros: Tough, withstands high temperatures, can be solvent-welded and vapor-smoothed.
cons: Warps significantly, off-gases during printing.

name: ASA
description: ASA is a chemical cousin of ABS but with better UV resistance and less warping. It has a handsome matte surface.
pros: Better UV resistance, less warping, matte surface.
cons: Off-gases during printing, requires enclosure.

name: HIPS
description: HIPS is used as support material for ASA or ABS. It is slightly flexible and has low density.
pros: Flexible, low density, dissolvable in limonene.
cons: Soft and waxy, low bed adhesion.

name: PA-6 Nylon
description: PA-6 Nylon is exceptionally strong and flexible. It is stable at high temperatures but is hygroscopic and warps easily.
pros: High strength, flexible, high-temperature stability.
cons: Hygroscopic, warps easily, requires heated chamber.

name: PA-12 Nylon
description: PA-12 Nylon is stiffer than PA-6 and prints at higher temperatures. It is brittle and warps more than PA-6.
pros: Stiffer, higher temperature resistance.
cons: More brittle, warps more, expensive.

name: PA-6 CF Nylon
description: PA-6 CF Nylon is stiffer and warps less than regular nylon but still requires high-end equipment to print properly.
pros: Stiffer, reduced warping.
cons: Requires high-end equipment, expensive.

name: PA-12 CF Nylon
description: PA-12 CF Nylon is even stiffer than PA-6 CF but sacrifices some of nylon's low friction properties.
pros: Extremely stiff.
cons: Sacrifices low friction, very expensive.

name: Glass-Filled Nylon
description: Glass-Filled Nylon is tough, durable, and resistant to heat, abrasion, and impact. It is easier to print than pure nylon.
pros: Extremely tough, durable, heat and abrasion-resistant.
cons: Requires high-end printer, very abrasive.

name: Nylon/PETG Alloys
description: Nylon/PETG Alloys combine properties of nylon and PETG but inherit many of their weaknesses, such as warping.
pros: Improves PETG's strength.
cons: Tends to warp, not as strong as pure nylon.

name: Polycarbonate (PC)
description: Polycarbonate is very tough and stiff, with a glass-like sheen. It absorbs water quickly and is slow to print.
pros: Very tough, stiff, clear.
cons: Absorbs water quickly, slow to print, prints at very high temperatures.

name: CF Polycarbonate
description: CF Polycarbonate is extremely stiff and rough, making it suitable for high-strength applications.
pros: Extremely stiff, rough, affordable.
cons: Requires high-performance printer, abrasive.

name: PMMA (Acrylic)
description: PMMA is highly transparent and UV resistant, but it is brittle and absorbs water.
pros: Highly transparent, UV resistant, can be polished.
cons: Brittle, absorbs water, poor bed and layer adhesion.

name: PC-PBT
description: PC-PBT is an alloy of polycarbonate and PBT, offering excellent surface quality and low warping.
pros: Excellent surface quality, low warping, durable in cold temperatures.
cons: Requires high-temperature printing, difficult to find.

name: Chocolate
description: Chocolate is the only printable and edible thermoplastic. It prints at very low temperatures.
pros: Edible, prints at low temperatures.
cons: Not suitable for structural parts.

name: TPU
description: TPU is tough, flexible, and available in various hardnesses. It absorbs water quickly but is easy to print.
pros: Tough, flexible, available in various hardnesses, easy to print.
cons: Absorbs water quickly, requires dehydrator.

name: TPE
description: TPE is flexible and stretchy but difficult to print due to its runny nature.
pros: Flexible and stretchy.
cons: Difficult to print, prints often look poor.

name: SEBS
description: SEBS is a form of TPE enhanced with the same chemical that makes ABS perform well. It is flexible, stretchy, and smooth to print.
pros: Flexible, stretchy, smooth to print.
cons: Hygroscopic, off-gases during printing.

name: Polypropylene (PP)
description: Polypropylene is very rugged and has excellent tensile strength but is difficult to print due to poor bed adhesion and warping.
pros: Rugged, excellent tensile strength, low density.
cons: Poor bed adhesion, warps significantly, difficult to print.

name: Glass-Filled Polypropylene
description: Glass-Filled Polypropylene is tough and durable but extremely difficult to print due to poor bed adhesion and warping.
pros: Extremely tough, durable, lightweight.
cons: Poor bed adhesion, warps significantly, requires high-end printer.

name: OBC (Olefin Block Copolymers)
description: OBC is semi-flexible and has improved warping properties over polypropylene but is still difficult to print.
pros: Semi-flexible, low warping, can use supports.
cons: Difficult to print, expensive, requires special build surface.

name: HDPE (High-Density Polyethylene)
description: HDPE is very tough but has extremely poor bed adhesion and warps significantly.
pros: Very tough, low density, recycled polymer.
cons: Extremely poor bed adhesion, warps significantly, difficult to print.

name: POM (Polyoxymethylene)
description: POM is stiff and has low friction but has extremely poor bed adhesion and off-gases harmful chemicals.
pros: Stiff, low friction.
cons: Extremely poor bed adhesion, off-gases harmful chemicals, difficult to print.

name: PVDF (Polyvinylidene Fluoride)
description: PVDF is tough, durable, and chemically resistant but off-gases toxic fumes if overheated.
pros: Tough, durable, chemically resistant, hydrophobic.
cons: Off-gases toxic fumes if overheated, expensive.

name: PEEK (Polyether Ether Ketone)
description: PEEK is extremely strong and heat-resistant but very expensive and difficult to print.
pros: Extremely strong, heat-resistant, chemical-resistant.
cons: Very expensive, difficult to print, requires specialized equipment.

name: PEKK (Polyether Ketone Ketone)
description: PEKK is similar to PEEK but easier to print and still offers excellent strength and chemical resistance.
pros: Excellent strength, easier to print than PEEK, chemical-resistant.
cons: Expensive, requires specialized equipment.

name: PPS (Polyphenylene Sulfide)
description: PPS is chemically resistant and practical to print but still requires high-temperature printing.
pros: Chemically resistant, practical print parameters.
cons: Requires high-temperature printing, expensive.

name: PSU (Polysulfone)
description: PSU is heat-resistant, radiation-resistant, and chemical-resistant, with properties similar to PA-6 Nylon.
pros: Heat-resistant, radiation-resistant, chemical-resistant.
cons: Difficult to print, expensive.

name: PES (Polyether Sulfone) and PPSU (Polyphenylsulfone)
description: PES and PPSU are exceptionally rugged, heat-resistant, and chemical-resistant super polymers.
pros: Rugged, heat-resistant, chemical-resistant.
cons: Difficult to print, very expensive.

name: Ultem 1010
description: Ultem 1010 is a super polymer with excellent strength, stability, and heat resistance.
pros: Excellent strength, stability, heat-resistant.
cons: Very expensive, difficult to print, requires specialized equipment.

name: TPI (Thermoplastic Polyimide)
description: TPI is extremely heat-resistant but very difficult to print, requiring very high temperatures and specialized equipment.
pros: Extremely heat-resistant.
cons: Very difficult to print, requires very high temperatures and specialized equipment.
